“She Came In Through the Bathroom Window” segues abruptly after “Polythene Pam”, the song on the preceding track, without pause. At the very beginning of the song, in anticipation of the change of tempo, John Lennon gives out a laugh and then shouts “Oh, look out!”[4]
And so I quit the police department

The inspiration for this line came in October 1968, when Paul was traveling in a taxi to JFK airport with Linda Eastman and her daughter Heather. Looking at the driver’s identification panel, he noticed that it read ‘Eugene Quits, New York Police Department.’

“So I got ‘So I quit the police department’, which are part of the lyrics to that. This was the great thing about the randomness of it all. If I hadn’t been in this guy’s cab, or if it had been someone else driving, the song would have been different. Also I had a guitar there so I could solidify it into something straight away.” – Paul, 1997

Sunday’s on the phone to Monday
 Tuesday’s on the phone to me

This may be a reference to the 19th century nursery rhyme “Monday’s child”, where Sunday’s (the Sabbath) child “is bonny and blithe, and good and gay”, who is calling Monday’s child, or simply “Monday” in the track, where Monday’s child “is fair of face”. Tuesday’s Child “is full of Grace” Tuesday is calling me, so me must be Wednesday, or Wednesday’s child, the one who “is full of woe”, perhaps because of the strange circumstance happening in his bathroom and with life in general in the spotlight.

And though she thought I knew the answer
 Well, I knew what I could not say

This was written when the Beatles, and by extension Paul McCartney, were absolutely the most famous, most studied group in the world of pop and rock. Their lyrics were dissected and analyzed by everyone from scholars to the Manson family, their album covers examined for clues to whether or not Paul was dead.

In this lyric, Paul is saying that fangirls like the one that broke into his home, and the world at large, thought he had an answer, a “truth” for them. But the only truth he had was a personal one, as the songs were ultimately personal for him, not universal.
She could steal, but she could not rob

To a policeman, “robbery” is a legal category and punishable offense. Policeman Paul would be obligated to come down hard on this bird.
But if he were to quit the police department to become a regular bloke with a steady job, it’s just “stealing.” There wouldn’t have to be any legal consequence.

She said she’d always been a dancer
 She worked at fifteen clubs a day

The woman in question is a dancing girl and she’s been around, which is fine and perfectly acceptable.

She “works” at 15 clubs because, she’s not there to dance, she’s there to pick up clients that she can take home.

But now she sucks her thumb and wanders
 By the banks of her own lagoon

She is immature, and possibly sheltered, due to her silver spoon (wealthy) life and she is acting childish once inside the house (wandering around in amazement, stealing things, doing what she wants).

The expression “silver spoon” means to be privileged or come from a privileged background.
In this line, Paul is saying that this girl is “protected by her silver spoon” and thus is not afraid of getting into trouble by sneaking into his house (the wealth that she comes from could probably get her out of any trouble, ie: rich parents paying off police, etc.)
She came in through the bathroom window

Paul McCartney wrote this about a fan who broke into his house. Diane Ashley claims it was her:

We found a ladder in his garden and stuck it up the bathroom window which he’d left slightly open. I was the one who climbed up and got in."



Now married with 4 children, Diane keeps a framed photo of herself with Paul on her kitchen shelf and looks back on her days as an Apple Scruff with affection:

I don’t regret any of it. I had a great time, a really great time."
